fields.Journal: Physical Review A-Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
fields.Description/Abstract: <span style="font-size:14.0063px;">The behavior of excitons in organic dye aggregates is well characterized by the Frenkel model</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">when dyes are packed sufficiently close that electric dipole-dipole coupling between dyes is in the</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">strong coupling regime where coherent exciton transfer between dyes is shorter than the exciton</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">dephasing time. Here we show that the interactions contained within the Frenkel model enable the</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">construction of an exciton transistor in which a single exciton residing on a gate molecule controls the</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">flow of excitons in a gate channel consisting of an array of molecules along which excitons propagate</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">ballistically. The difference static-dipole interaction enables the implementation of a gate structure</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">that functions as a switchable Bragg grating thereby enabling high on-off ratios in excess of 10</span><span style="font-size:9.33756px;">2</span><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">. The</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">device can function as a quantum gate in which the gate molecule and channel subsystems become</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">entangled when the gate molecule is prepared in a superposition state consisting of the presence or</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">absence of an exciton.</span><span style="font-size:14.0063px;"> </span><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">The resulting state is a superposition in which a large number of excitons</span><br><span style="font-size:14.0063px;">either have passed through the gate or have reflected off of the gate.</span>
